statistics.description: The number of points scored.

statistics.description: Field Goal makes and attempts.

statistics.name: freeThrows

statistics.name: assists
statistics.description: The number of times a player who passes the ball to a teammate in a way that leads to a score by field goal, meaning that he or she was "assisting" in the basket. There is some judgment involved in deciding whether a passer should be credited with an assist.

statistics.name: turnovers
statistics.description: The number of times a player loses possession to the other team.

statistics.name: minutes
statistics.description: The total number of minutes played.

statistics.name: assistTurnoverRatio
statistics.description: The average number of assists a player or team records per turnover

statistics.name: rebounds
statistics.description: The total number of rebounds (offensive and defensive).

statistics.name: defensiveRebounds
statistics.description: The number of times when the defense obtains the possession of the ball after a missed shot by the offense.

statistics.name: offensiveRebounds
statistics.description: The number of times when the offense obtains the possession of the ball after a missed shot.

article.headline: Wake Forest 87, Winston-Salem 71
article.story: WINSTON-SALEM, N.C. (AP) -- Kyle Visser had 15 points and 11 rebounds to lead six Wake Forest players finishing in double figures Tuesday in an 87-71 victory over Winston-Salem. Jamie Skeen had his second career double-double with 11 points and a career-high 13 rebounds for the Demon Deacons (11-12, 2-8 Atlantic Coast Conference) in the first-ever meeting of the cross-town, non-conference teams. L.D. Williams and Harvey Hale scored 12 points each, and Anthony Gurley and Michael Drum both came off the bench to score 11 points apiece for Wake Forest. Brian Fisher hit six 3-pointers and finished with 25 points and Darrell Wonge added 17 for the Rams (4-21), who fought back from double-digit deficits three times in the first half to pull within six points at halftime. Winston-Salem, in its first full season in Division I, went up 3-2 on Fisher's 3-pointer with 19:02 left. But the Demon Deacons went on a 21-6 run over the next eight minutes, with eight straight points by Anthony Gurley putting Wake Forest ahead 23-9 with 11:07 remaining. The Rams managed to pull back within three points. Back-to-back 3-pointers by Wonge cut the Demon Deacons' lead to 23-20 with 7:28 left, and Winston-Salem trailed 44-38 at the break. Wake Forest opened the second half with an 18-8 run to push its lead back into double digits for good. The Demon Deacons led by as many as 20 points later in the half, going ahead 77-57 on a pair of Visser free throws with 6:15 remaining. Winston-Salem spent nearly three decades in Division II. The Rams, playing as an independent this season, will join the Mid-Eastern Athletic Conference next year.
